content: CRISPR-Cas9 is a revolutionary gene-editing technology that allows precise modifications to DNA sequences.
The human brain uses approximately 20% of the body's total energy despite representing only 2% of body weight.
The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest coral reef system, stretching over 2,300 kilometers off Australia's coast.
Binary code uses only two digits, 0 and 1, to represent all data in modern computers.
The Magna Carta, signed in 1215, established the principle that everyone, including the king, is subject to the law.
Greenhouse gases like CO2 and methane trap heat in Earth's atmosphere, contributing to global warming.
The Renaissance artist Michelangelo painted the Sistine Chapel ceiling between 1508 and 1512.
Antibodies are Y-shaped proteins produced by B-cells that bind to specific antigens to neutralize pathogens.
The speed of electricity through copper wire is approximately 95% the speed of light.
The printing press invention by Gutenberg around 1440 used movable type to mass-produce books.
Stem cells have the unique ability to differentiate into specialized cell types in the body.
The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989, symbolizing the end of the Cold War division in Europe.
Metabolic rate is the rate at which an organism converts food into energy, measured in calories per day.
The Turing Test, proposed by Alan Turing in 1950, evaluates a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior.
Beethoven composed his Ninth Symphony while completely deaf, premiering it in 1824.
